dataset.title: Meiobenthos abundance. Long-term variability and dynamics of estuarine meiobenthic populations (1973-1992).

associatedParty.role: Primary populations, vascular plants, ecosystem models

para.literalLayout: The original purpose of this research was to determine if natural meiobenthic assemblages exhibited continuity over time and to monitor several physical variables to determine if these influenced long-term temporal patterns. The most recent study focused on variation and the relations of meiobenthos abundance with environmental factors over 11 years. Typically marine benthic community studies are limited temporally and the majority of previously published 'longterm' meiofauna results (all taxa) were based on about a year's duration.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription:
North Inlet encompasses about 2,630 hectares of tidal marshes and wetlands near Georgetown, South Carolina, USA. North Inlet-Winyah Bay features high quality, ocean-dominated waters and salt marshes in North Inlet, contrasting with the brackish waters and marshes of Winyah Bay. The bay estuary is dominated by riverine discharges from a watershed impacted by agricultural, municipal and industrial development. Former rice fields and canals provide another system for study within the Reserve. The Debidue site is located at the confluence of Town Creek and Debidue Creek. The Bread and Butter site is located along the western shoreline of Town Creek adjacent to the mouth of Clambank Creek. The study site is the North Inlet marsh, a 3000 hectare high salinity estuary dominated by Spartina alterniflora, located approximately 6 km east of Georgetown, South Carolina. The marsh is bordered on the east by two barrier islands; on the south by a larger brackish estuary, Winyah Bay; and on the west and north by a mixed oak-pine forested peninsula.
Debidue Site (DD) - Debidue is a sand-bottomed site located approximately .5 km inside the Inlet mouth adjacent to the confluence of two major marsh creeks, Debidue and Town Creeks. The site is at the lower end of an extensive sand bar and is subject to strong current and wave action.
Bread and Butter Site (BB) - This site is located on a muddy subtidal bank of Bread and Butter Creek, about 100 m inside the mouth of this medium sized creek. The creek is 1.5 km SW of the Debidue site in the center of the marsh. The creek is 10 m wide at low tide at the sample site and is sheltered from strong current and wave action. The creek is lined with mud banks and oyster bars and the sediment at the sampling site is fine, silty mud.

para.literalLayout:
Each core sample was extruded and immediately fixed in 10 percent borax-buffered formalin with Rose Bengal. Salinity was measured by refractometer and Eh (September 1972 - December 1976) by platinum electrode. Oxidizable organic matter was determined using the wet dichromate method (Walkley and Black 1934). Granulometric parameters were measured by wet sieving through phi series sieves to 63 micrometers, and drying and weighing the sediment retained on the sieves. An aliquot of the material passing the 63 micrometer sieve was removed for pipette analysis (Folk 1968). Sorting coefficient was calculated using methods by Trask (1932).
Mud samples were extracted using Ludox centrifugation (de Jonge and Bowmann 1977); the sand samples by the shaking-supernatant technique of Wieser (1960). All animals retained on a 63 micrometer sieve were enumerated to major taxon; every copepod and every 4th nematode was removed for species identification. Since all sorted samples were formalin fixed, soft-bodied taxa abundance (e.g. gastrotrichs, turbellarians, ciliates) was probably underestimated (Hulings and Gray 1971). Ciliates may have been further underestimated since the samples were collected on a 63 micrometer sieve; thus only the larger ciliates (e.g. Tracheloraphis spp.) were retained.

The study sites (1 sand, 1 mud) in North Inlet, South Carolina, USA, were sampled monthly from January 1973 through December 1980 and every two weeks from January 1981 - December 1983. At each site 4 replicate core samples were taken up to March 1976, 3 replicates from April 1976 - December 1980 and 2 replicates from January 1981 December 1983. All cores were taken to the depth of the redox potential discontinuity (RPD); typically 1 to 2 centimeters in mud; 4 to 10 centimeters in sand. Both sites are subtidal, located 1 meter below MLW. Sediment samples were collected for organic analysis up to 1978, and for sediment size analysis monthly or quarterly (up to September 1979) and then monthly (March - December 1983). Four data sets were collected to assess potential temperature effects: (1) surface-sediment temperature measurements taken at the time of meiofauna sample collection (January 1973 - December 1983); (2) minimum and maximum daily air temperature recorded at the Georgetown County, SC, Airport from January 1935 - December 1978 (44 yr); (3) daily surface water temperatures from the mouth of the North Inlet estuary, June 1979 - December 1983; (4) heating and cooling degree days data collected at the Charleston Airport, Charleston, SC, December 1968 - April 1984.
